description.text: More testing of the scanner. Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

comments.text: Wow, that is REALLY awful! Have you simply hit the resolution limit of the scanner, or do you think you just need to tweak something? The specs of the scanner would IMPLY a dramatically better resolution than what I am seeing here, but I have observed that most scans I have seen from this scanner are pretty featureless and lumpy just like this one, which implies that that scanner itself is highly flawed.

author: RZRules

description.text:
Heart at the base, middle and top, surrounded by a wall of kisses If this doesn't shout romance then it's best to whisper. Good for Valentines. http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

As per the Twisted Heart Vase, Scale to suit.
Print (in red or paint it red).
Give as gift.
Feel the love. Print with zero infill, 1+ perimeters, and a few solid layers for the base. Either delete the last few layers of code or stop the print before it starts bridging the top, or cut off the solid layers after the print. With Slic3r 9.4 you can choose how many top solid layers you want. You want 0. I have also uploaded a shelled out (hollow opened topped) version of the vase with a 1mm wall thickness in case you prefer to programme that one instead.

UPDATED: added a super-strong version of of the bracket (SBH, Spool Bracket, Heavy). Whereas a stiff downward jerk would break the original version, the improved version will withstand much more force and weight. Use the original "2spool_bracket" at your own risk (it is also the one of the two that will fit in a Rep 2/2X spool slot). UPDATED AGAIN: Provided a "SnubWSB" (wire spool bracket), which is better suited for cramped (cough NEW YORK cough) places, but will only carry 1 5th gen spool. Wire racks, the kind sold by U-Line and other manufacturers of industrial equipment, are a fantastic solution for any number of storage situations, including Replicators and the filament they use.
This bracket is designed to hold filament spools outside of regular shelf space on these wire racks. They can hold up to 4 full 5th-generation spools at once, printed at 10% infill with only 2 shells (default Makerware low settings).
This bracket was designed explicitly with the long sides of the wire shelves in mind; it will not fit on the end caps.

Default low settings will make brackets that hold at least 8 lbs (spread across the arm).
I imagine higher shells and infill will provide even tougher structures.
This is an adapter plate that allows you to attach things to a popular Nerf toy Tripod. It has been useful for things like webcams and Microphones in my shop. It's my first upload.
Print this part and attach something to it. Enjoy a cheap modular tripod.

title: Support for DSLR or any camera - support pour appareil photo Reflex ou autres

description.text:
I will soon do a travel So I bought a camera (DSLR) for the occasion. But this summer I found that the camera is very heavy. And at the end of the day I felt like my neck was stiff.
So I decided to design a support that I can attach on the straps of a backpack.
Here it is
http://youtu.be/Rr-QORDyOXA
update 2014-09-07 http://youtu.be/MVUoe5bZkGk There is 2 other versions here:
the 2nd version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454364
and 3rd: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:454381

• The parts are given in the position they have to be printed.
  • 0,3mm precision is enough.
  • You might need to print with a support for some parts.
  • For the front part named "Support Reflex avant" there is 2 versions.
    I designed the second version "Support Reflex avant 2" for a better distribution of the screws force
  • You'll need tow 5mm screws In my situation the length was 25mm.
  • for the Tripo screw I used this one: http://cgi.ebay.fr/ws/eBayISAPI.dll?ViewItem&item=121288006551&ssPageName=STRK:MEWNX:IT&_trksid=p3984.m1497.l2649

comments.text: May I ask you, Would you like to share the 3d model with me ??
comments.author: stiliajohny

comments.text: Very Good Job, This is the accessory I was looking for!!!
comments.author: stiliajohny

comments.text:
Seen now the video. Everything makes sense. Havent noted the 90° secure movement and the presence of the original neck strap.
Nice test ground for ABS. It would be interesting to know if any fail happens and in how much time.
Any surface treathment with acetone?
Compliments!
comments.author: Karmarag

comments.text:
I made one and had a big of an issue like shown on the original, for the front bit. Nothing serious. Doing the camera attachment was a bit trickier because it needs support to print. You can create a bit of support in the design instead of printing with support.
Would be nice to post source so that people can make that small modification. I did it by importing the stl in sketchup and then adding support to the design (removed with a dremel after printing).
The screw that goes into the tripod mount is a bit tricky as it isn't standard thread. I used a screw from a quick-release plate of a tripod. A normal screw does not work.
comments.author: pauldebra

comments.text:
With what materiale are you printing it?
If your DSLR is "heavy" I would absolutely not thrust PLA or ABS. Even if they seem sturdy they'll surely fail in a fairly short time . . . maybe nylon or polycarbonate . . . (I would anyway add some extra latch and at least a release device to save your $$$ camera).
Just a word from a guy who happily uses a commercial DSLR belt.
comments.author: Karmarag

comments.text:
The support seems to be used to relieve the strain from the weight of the camera hanging from your neck. So what I do is to use the neck strap as usual and just use this support as extra security and to carry the weight. So it makes me feel more secure especially with my Olympus E-M5 which is a camera model that has seen some incidents of the strap lugs popping out. This support makes sure that the camera won't fall when a strap lug would fail.
By the way I printed with ABS (more "elastic" than PLA) and used 100% infil for extra strength.
comments.author: Karmarag

title: Raspberry Pi Model  A+  Raspberry Pi Model  B+ 10cm x 10cm monitor bracket

description.text:
This is a simple bracket for the back of a monitor or television that has 4 M3 threaded thresholds. The Raspberry Pi model A+ or model B+ sits on top without an enclosure.
I have not printed this part out and do not know how well it will print so use at your own risk.
Once printed out you will need to carefully drill out counter sinks for the 4 holes that the screw heads of the screws that mount the Raspberry Pi to the bracket.

Steampunk goggles V2!
The radialengine_10gear-all.stl is designed to print as a single piece. I am going to upload a nosepiece at some point that should fit snugly between the outer ring and the goggle body.
18 August: A new file, radialengine_12gear.STL, has been uploaded. It prints a heck of a lot nicer, and the shield is much nicer as well. I highly recommend using this file insteasd of the 10gear version

Print it, paint it, wear with nerdpride.
Use 52mm colored photography filters (they should fit quite nicely) for a nice look!
18 August: There is some after-print finishing work that needs doing. The slots for the strap need cleaning (some of the bottom noodles have trouble adhering in the proper spot if you don't print with supports, which I try not to do). The double nose-piece might also need some trimming as arcs are hard to print without underlying support. I didn't use supports and had little trouble with it.

comments.text:
Ahh! So many likes and adds to other people's collections! :)
I printed out the single piece print yesterday and quickly realized that some mods were needed. I will be uploading the new STL files at some point this week.
Mods include increasing the radial spokes from 11 to 12, a less unibrow-y nosepiece (with a second pair of arcs - possibly more steampunky as well), and a vastly more aesthetically-pleasing shield and embossed gear.
I think I will add several different goggle widths (akin to pupil distance, or PD, for those of us glasses-wearing folk), so if you have larger or smaller faces, you can print out the first few layers of one or three and see what size is most comfortable.
Cheers!
-DAstronomer

Parametric lasercuttable box with box joints and a top lid to open and close it easily.
I just took Peteruithoven's box and adapted it to have a slidable lid.

You can change the box height, width and height, the material thickness and the offset for the laser beam.
You can either use asembly3D to preview it or the export() module to lay everything flat, then export it as DXF.

Print in flexible material. for diameter 1" & 0.060" (25.4mm, 1.5mm) thick steel tube often used for poles on trampolines.
I used 1.5mm2 cable through it but use any type of cord that will fit...
Use many layers when printing to get a strong part.
I used my own PI-ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament material but it contained some moisture (my bad, did not store it dry...) thus the rough surface on the picture... Please check out my unique UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/

description.text: A 3-d printer friendly version of the Rigidbot "Z" bracket.

Prints best with the flat side laying on the print bed. This orientation keeps the overhangs to a minimum, keeps any distortion to the through holes to areas not affected by any inaccuracies, and keeps the print layers orientated perpendicular to the direction force is applied by the machine.

A replacement rigidbot limit switch holder. The stock rigidbot part has a brass threaded insert on the positioning screw. This version includes a hexagonal cut out on the inside of the hole for the 8mm rod that is sized to fit a standard M3 nut. This will allow the positioning screw to be tightened down firmly like the stock part to maintain position on the rod.

I recommend printing this part with the 8mm rod holes perpendicular to the print bed. This will keep the 8mm rod hole free of distortion and the force applied by the screws will be orientated in the strongest direction on the printed part.

This is the same holder but with extra 3mm in length/width/thickness to be able to accomodate a protective case/shell with 1.5mm thickness.  
NOTE: I have not tested this and would appreciate feedback.

comments.text: Wow, just got it from the printer today. Printed in ABS, and it came out perfect! VERY impressive, especially since it was modified only from my measurements of the skin/cover.
comments.author: jwjl

comments.text: After looking at the parts list, I'm not sure how you are driving the stepper motors. The list specifies 2 L293D driver chips, but each L293D can only drive one stepper.
comments.author: NickAmes

comments.text: Thanks for catching the L293D error Nick, that should be 4.
comments.author: NickAmes

comments.text: In that case, you'll need different stepper motors, because according to lin engineering's spec page for yours (3518X-04) they have only 7.5 oz-in. (.05 Nm) of holding (absolute maximum) torque, which is .039 lb-ft of torque, or 16% of the gear motor you mentioned.
comments.author: TheRat

comments.text: yep your right, the NEMA 14 are rated in in-oz, could have sworn those were lbft for some reason. Ehh, I was hoping to stick with a set of Nema motors since they're a lot easier to get a hold of in the USA (versus the 3 month wait I had from Mafukbu).
comments.author: NickAmes

comments.text: Hey Nick, thanks for pointing out the issues with this project so far.  It's been fun trying to recreate the old cad drawings, but it will be even more fun getting this thing running all over the place.
comments.author: TheRat

comments.text: Alright, fire up printer and dig out your Arduinos, here's a robot so many people have been asking for. Project Alpha is a robot heavily based off of that old Zoid cartoon series but the premise was to build a fully autonomous robot that could be addapted for small point to point tasks around the house. Unfortunately, the lack of knowledge to affordable electronics shelved the project for the past two years but after seeing the current performance out of the Nema and Arduinos, this project now looks affordable to the average consumer.
comments.author: TheRat

title: Sticky Note and Pen holder for Fridge

description.text:
My co-workers wanted a way to mark the food in the shared fridge with our name and date without having to permanently mark our containers (otherwise food would be forgotten/wasted). The sticky notes and pens were out of sight and out of mind so I created this to stick onto the fridge.
This thing has 3 holes in the back to fit the magnets I had spares of, about 4mm dia. and 3mm deep, but you might have different magents.
The holder can fit either the 3in. or 2in pads, the slot cut in the center allows easy access to the smaller pads. The pen hole was actually measured to fit up to a standard Sharpie marker.

MakerWare 1.0 oriented upright and multiple mouse ears (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:38272) on the corners
Miracle Grue Medium settings
15% infill
2 shells
.25mm layer thickness
230C temp
80mm/sec speed My Replicator 2 likes to squash vertical holes, so the holes for the magnets had to be cleaned up, but only a little bit so that the magnets could still be friction fit.

author: JackJ106

title: Smitten the Mitten
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Meet Smitten, he's a blue mitten. No one wants to play with smitten unless it's below freezing. Most people don't agree with Smitten about winter being the best time of year, but I sure do. Three quarters of the year no one wants anything to do with Smitten, but when the flurries fly and your grass has frost on it in the morning, then everyone wants to be best friends with Smitten.
Smitten is sad and blue from all this part time friendship and could use a loyal friend like yourself to print him out and give a home on your desk. He'd much rather be on your desk or bookshelf then in a dry storage tub for three quarters of the year. Check out our Kickstarter at:
http://kck.st/1FpgTpD

Print with raft, no support needed. Smitten was printed with 10% infill and a raft. Once printed all that is needed for clean up is an sharp edge to remove the stringies.
We also used a paint marker just to color the centers of the eyes black.

title: Girlie Sandals & Hat for Corkasaurus Rex

description.text:

The sundress is actually the Prom Dress from thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:354563. The bows in the first photo are the smaller ones; the second photo shows the larger sandal bows.
I used 0.2 mm layers, 3 shells and 20% infill.  No support or raft was required, although the latter may be important in some circumstances.

I was using the Beefed Up Replicator Extruder Bracket from MangoT21.. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26880 But the problem i had was that when you tightened it down the front edge could dip down because of the heatsinks and the back end would raise up a bit, this made the filament go in at a slight angle and it would rub on the extruder feed block a bit so i modified it slightly adding a shim to the front end to raise it up so the back end would be flush to the top of the stepper motors. I also modified the opening for the wiring by removing the two points that continued in on the circle opening for the wiring, this lets the wiring lay down easier when you install the wiring strain relief, which i might also redesign at some point now also.
100% infill, no support.

My first attempt to design sandals for my son. I printed it using my own TPU filament ( I developed my own filament extruder to be able to get excellent tolerances with problematic materials )
Modelled aprox 233mm long and 96mm wide, Print http://palmiga.com/3dfiles/Palmiga_Sandals_v0.2.pdf on A4 to compare with your foot and rescale to your size. Please also check out my unique UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/

I've seen some other bumpers out there for the 2560 but none seemed to fit for some reason when I printed them on my Makerbot Replicator 2.  
So, I took direct measurements from my boards and worked up my own bumper.  Created a thick-walled version and a thin-walled version.  I've found the thick-walled version hangs onto the board better because its more rigid but the board doesn't fit back in the box with the thick-walled version (#tradeoffs).

This was made using AutoCAD Inventor LT Suite. Measurements were pulled from two Ardiuno Mega 2560 boards via digital calipers. Print-tested on a Makerbot Replicator 2 at standard quality setting, 1 shell and 10% infill using Makerbot filament. I was inspired to create this after trying a few other bumper designs that didn't seem to be sized correctly when printed on my printer / configuration. Please check out http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:64008 - Kelleyegan has a nice parametric code-base for OpenSCAD going for multiple Arduino boards

description.text: Annoyed with couch cover always slipping off? Well slide an edge of the fabric in, tighten the clamp, and shove between the cushions.

Used a 1in #10 bolt and nut.
The nut is squeezed into the slide (very tight fit to stay in place).
The slide is slid into the anchor
The bolt is put through the hole in the front of the anchor and threaded into the nut.
Then place an edge into the opening and tighten the bolt.
The slide will tighten on the fabric
Then slip the anchor between the cushions.
Done!
The slide is printed with our support or raft
The anchor is printed with support and no raft

v1 of the Burrito. A MFMD organizer.

This is a wimshurst machine that you can print at almost no cost; home made bearings are used and I collected stuff laying around for other parts. It is important to keep charge leaks at a minimum, so try to not have any straight metal edges where corona discharge can happen. Also, depending on your leyden jars size, be safe, try to not kill yourself with the thousands of volts (shouldn't happen since the current is minimal, unless you customize your leyden jars and make them too big). https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=23ukTKdDZKU

• For reference, please see how a wimshurst actually works and how it is built: http://steampunkworkshop.com/how-build-wimshurst-influence-machine-part-1
    • Print all files, you will need a frame on each side (supportA and supportB 2x) Print 48 sectors for 2 discs, glue 24 sectors together on the hub assembly, or use 2 acrylic rotors if you want a sturdier and precise rotor. The bearings use copper BB Guns pellet (0.177 caliber).
    You might have to adjust clearance of the bearings depending on your print quality! Use an electric motor that fits the frame, I personally used an old HP printer motor. Cut the sectors in aluminum tape using the SectorTemplate model. Assemble the 2 collectors using copper wire, I used standard 14 gauge wire.
    I used springs on the collectors, these collect the charge and bring them down to the capacitors (leyden jars). Leyden jars are made using kapton tape. I am still testing the caps parameters, but I currently applied 3 layers of kapton on the outside of the leyden jars and 1 width of aluminum tape inside and outside, keeping clearance from top and bottom of the leyden jars. ABS plastic actually isn't that good an insulator, maybe this is due to the fact that extruded plastic is not 100% air tight? I used "fondue" forks for the spark gap, I removed the fork and replaced it with a printed ball with aluminum tape on it. This is far from ideal, but I didn't have brass balls laying around, so I did it cheaply for the moment... I also used 3 printer metal rollers as conductors spacing to connect spark gap and capacitor external plates. The external plate connector should have brass balls on it too, to prevent charge leaking. I have much leaking currently with this setup, so I am limited in spark length, I can have 2 inches sparks, but with a proper electrical setup, this could be much more improved! I consider this as a proof of concept, more than a perfect machine, feel free to experiment! Assembly should be straight forward from there.

comments.text: Hello there! That's a very nicely designed Wimhurst. I've been an electrostatics enthusiast for a long time but aside from some ill fated friction machines I built years ago my primary means of building a charge is with a straight section of PVC and some sort of cloth. Since you've actually put this little beauty together and tested it how does the ABS perform? At the dallas makerspace we've got a laser cutter and I've been fooling around with the acrylic sheets, trying to decide which route would be best to make an influence machine with. While I've been plagued with indecision it seems you've gone and beaten me to the prize! I commend you! Have you thought of creating any other machines? Electrostatic motors? Perhaps one of A.D. Moore's Dirod generators? (That's what I was planning on doing.) I will be looking into your custom bearings with great interest!

title: PLA Spring Motor, Rolling Chassis
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Just discovered this thing is featured! Thanks Thingiverse! And thanks to the viewers, "likers", downloaders, commenters and followers! A rolling chassis version of the PLA Spring Motor (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:402412), printed entirely in PLA, spring and all, requiring no batteries, bearings, screws, power supply, electric or drill motors to operate. Wheelie, an updated wheelie pulling dragster version of this thing is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:452248. Video of upgraded wheel design (see UPDATE below) showing a 40 foot run is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_w1LrRPG0Uo&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA&index=1. With the wife's assistance, it hits the baseboard at 40 feet, but has enough energy to run further. Video of original wheel design is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MzcdfTisBjk&index=1&list=UUv_zm49u-RjnCJVwhUO-ecA. I did not have a large short carpet area to run it on, but I estimate it would run 30+ feet on short carpet. As you can see in the video, it spins out once it reaches the hard floor, indicating a waste of whatever energy was remaining in the PLA spring. The first photo is of the original PLA Spring Motor, Rolling Chassis. The second is with the updated rear wheels and axles. The original prototype works best on short carpet with the original wheels as it will spin out on hard floors or when wound to 100%. With the updated wheels and axle (see UPDATE below) it works best on hard surfaces and will run 40 feet plus. UPDATE: I've uploaded two new files, "Axle Rear Slotted.stl" and "Wheel Rear Slotted.stl". The new wheel allows for a rubber band tire, and the new axle allows for the new wheel width, both of which allow the PLA Spring Motor, Rolling Chassis to run on hard floors. The prototype runs an average of 40' (approximately 12 meters) across a hard surface before coming to a stop. UPDATE 2: I've uploaded "Pawl New.stl", use this if your slicer has trouble with "Pawl.stl". Use safety glasses when operating the PLA Spring Motor, Rolling Chassis. While I've operated the mechanism well over a hundred times without a failure, I always recommend erring on the side of caution as the spring could snap and send pieces flying where they shouldn't be flying, and that's never a good thing. Designed using Sketchup 8, and printed in PLA on a Makerbot Replicator 2 using Makerware 2.3.3.42.

Use safety glasses when operating the PLA Spring Motor, Rolling Chassis. While I've operated the mechanism well over a hundred times without a failure, I always recommend erring on the side of caution as the spring could snap and send pieces flying where they shouldn't be flying, and that's never a good thing.  
Carefully study "Assembly.skp". Note that the .skp file should be used as an assembly diagram and not be used to print parts as the parts in the .skp file may not be the final parts as found in the .stl files.  
Print all PLA parts from the .stl files. Print "Knob.stl" and "Spring.stl" with Makerware "Standard" settings modified for 100% infill, the remaining parts using Makerware "Standard" settings with the default infill.  
Test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding will be required.   
Assemble as per "Assembly.skp".  
Lubricate moving surfaces with light machine oil.   
Comment if questions.  
Hope you like it!

comments.text: Designing gears is science (there are numerous gear design documents that can be found on the internet, most of which are quite accurate); designing gears for 3D printing is an art.  Of primary concern is making sure the ratio of number of teeth and the pitch radius remains constant.  However, when 3D printing a gear train, you must take into account a number of issues, none the least of which is what I call "oozing".  If your build plate is too close to the print head, or you are extruding too much PLA, the gear teeth will be too close to mesh efficiently, thus they will bind.  Again here there is much to be said for trial and error, since one cannot guarantee that what I print on my printer with the Makerware "default" settings, will print on your printer with your settings.

The print time turns out to be about 1 hour and 45 min.  And most of this time is spent "travelling" and not printing.  I used slic3r to slice it but that generated only 6 or 7 layers, and seems to think that the spring is only 2.4 mm high.  I have tried printing it twice so far with Cura, but both of the time it failed.  First time, it clogged which I believe is because of too much travelling and not as much printing which tends to make the hot filament clog.  And second time, it just stopped at 5.2 mm height and I don't know why because I was not around, and Cura was showing option to Print (the Print button was re-enabled) that makes me think that it thought it was done printing. description.text: Same diameter as my SainSmart spool spindle, but with a shorter shoulder and 3.6" tall from shoulder to top for the Matter Hackers spools.

This is my version of the curved fan duct for a Mendelmax 2.0 . It is in one part for simplicity and strength.
I had problems with the standard 40mm fan duct which was a 2-piece part. It needed to be screwed together and I found that was a weakness point when I went through several mounting brackets. The parts just fell apart after heavy use at full Mendelmax 2 speeds - which is very fast!
UPDATE 17/8/2014: Version 2 part. It is now is a little bit longer (5mm) so the nozzle should be centred now.
UPDATE 4/9/2014: Flat version of part that is rotated flat for printing.
http://youtu.be/iGj08E992UU
UPDATE 4/12/2015: Added Solidworks part file on request of user to modify for their MM2.
Print this with the fan plate at the bottom.  The maximum overhang angle is 45° so it should print fine on most printers.

title: Pachinko Style Savings Bank
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: A fun way to save for a couple different things. Especially if you cant decide what you want more. The slide plate is done in 2 separate pieces to allow it to fit on the build plate. All pieces are designed so no supports are required, though some may require you to turn them when printing.

You need to print 1 of each part with 2 exceptions (Part 15 does not exist. It was integrated into part 16). The Drawer and the Drawer Face. Those parts you need to print 2 of each. All parts are, for the most part, self aligning, It is easier to assemble if you do the base with the drawers first. Do the upper slide piece. And then do the cap piece. They are all separate modules that then can be put together.
This was printed on a Makerbot Rep 2 at .2/layer using PLA. I was set to 15% infill, with the exception of the locking rod. That was printed using 100% infill for strength.

I do the same with Slic3r and Cura from Rep host, it is nice to be able to use really any slicer you want.

title: Use 3/8th Rod and Acme Nut on PB Simple 1405

description.text:
This is replacement for Part 1115 on the Printrbot Simple 1405 Maker's Edition.
Printrbot sells the 11" x 3/8" Acme Rod, Acme Nut and 5mm to 3/8" inch Coupler for larger Printrbot Models. This will allow you to use those parts on your Simple Makers Edition.
This part requires that you pause the print when the nut cavity is tall enough to accept the 3/8" acme nut. Pause the printer, press the nut to the bottom of the cavity and then continue your print. This will embed/seal the part inside the modified part 1115.
I printed this part using the 0.4mm nozzle, set for 0.2mm filament height and only 2 perimeters. Monitor the gcode preview of the print software to make sure you pause the print before it starts to close the embedded area.
It is a tight fit, so there is no backlash from the nut shifting. To help press the nut into the part, flat and level, thread it onto the end of the z rod (before installing) and use the 3/8"th z rod to press it into the part. Remove the rod and continue printing.

title: Guardians of the Galaxy Infinity Orb / Stone / Gem UPDATED 2014-11-13

description.text:
UPDATE 11-13-2014
.
I'm nearly finished with my orb! I added pictures of the (near) final paint job. Last thing I need to do is make a few minor improvements to the stl files, then I'll replace all these updates with detailed instructions.
.
UPDATE 11-02-2014
.
I have my rims and my orbs glued together, Bondo-ed, primed with filler sealer and sanded (4 times), and just about ready to paint with the final colors. There will be a few additional changes to the .stl files, including hidden mounting holes for magnets and a few more thickenings of thin edges. But we're getting close!
.
UPDATE 10-15-2014
.
I updated ExteriorNew.stl in order to make some of the thin walls thicker and fix a few things here and there. I'm printing it out now. If all goes well, I'm hoping it will be the final draft.
.
UPDATE 10-01-2014
.
The printing of the new exterior is complete, and it looks great at .1mm layer height, .4mm nozzle, 13 percent infill, and no supports. It took about 20 hours to print (one half sphere, that is.) See first picture.
.
UPDATE 10-01-2014
.
I'm about 3/4 through with printing the new exterior, which is enough to say that it is printing without supports VERY WELL. If anyone was holding off until that was confirmed, you are clear to start printing.
.
UPDATE 09-30-2014
.
I removed the old version of the exterior so as not to cause confusion.
.
UPDATE 09-30-2014
.
I uploaded a new version of ExteriorNEW that gets rid of the support tower. In order to make the dome print without support structures, I made the upper interior conical with a slightly-less steep overhang than the sphere. Print at your own risk. I'll let you know in 18 hours if it works.
.
UPDATE 09-30-2014
.
I tried printing the ExteriorNEW last night. When I woke up this morning, I found that the support column broke, which caused the plastic to block the path and stagger the resulting layers. So now I'm working on a slightly thicker support column.
.
UPDATE 09-30-2014.
.
Ok, I finally finished the new exterior! In order to make it easier to print without supports, it is in two files: "GuardiansGalaxyInfinityOrbExteriorNEW" and "GuardiansGalaxyInfinityOrbRim." Print ExteriorNEW without support structures. I included a support column inside the orb as a part of the print. Break it off when ExteriorNEW is finished printing. I recommend using support structures on OrbRim. At any rate, print each and glue together to form one-half of an orb. Then print both again to form the other half.
.
These two files are hot off the press, so I can't guarantee they will print flawlessly. I printed the rims, and they align nicely. I'm printing the ExteriorNew as I write this. 16 more hours to go in an 18 hour print! I'm leaving the old version of the exterior up for now in case the new version gives anyone trouble. That being said, if you print ExteriorNEW and OrbRim, you WON'T need to print the old file called GuardiansGalaxyInfinityOrbExterior.
.

.
Here's my attempt at replicating the Infinity Orb from the film Guardians of the Galaxy. It's a work-in-progress. So far I've completed the outer shell (second draft), the rim (first draft), and both halves of the interior (final draft).
.
In one of the pictures, you can see a side by side comparison of my orb and the orb from the film. I tried to replicate all the hole shapes to the best of my ability.
.
UPDATE: 09-20-2014. A user was having trouble printing the interior because of the bottom later being two separate pieces. I added some planks connecting the two pieces. Hopefully this will fix the problem. I'm STILL working on an updated exterior. It's taking me longer than expected. I hope to have it up sometime next week.
.
UPDATE: 08-31-2014. I was able to successfully print the interior. It fits nicely inside the exterior. I made slight modifications to the Side A and Side B files, in order to fix a few things. The new versions are now uploaded. I'm making progress on the new version of the exterior, which I'll post soon.
.
UPDATE: 8-30-2114.
"Interior Side B" is now posted. If all goes well, it should interlock with Side A. As with Side A, print without support structures. Next up, a slight redesign of the exterior to make it printable without support structures.
.
UPDATE: 8-28-2114. "Interior Side A" is now slicing correctly. It's going to show it's not manifold, but you can ignore this. I already ran this (and all my STLs) through Netfabb. Print the interior WITHOUT support structures.
.
UPDATE: 8-27-2014. I uploaded Interior Side A, the first of two interior halfs. It's designed to fit in the exterior with just enough lip for you to glue it in purposefully tilted on the axis. I designed it so that you don't need to use support structures. I don't recommend printing this part just yet, as there are some slicing errors. I'll let you know when I get it repaired.
.
UPDATE: 8-18-2014. 18 hours after beginning the print, I have half an orb! The support structures are proving to be extremely difficult to remove, but it did actually print correctly.
.
UPDATE: 8-18-2014. I uploaded a new version. The file is still not manifold, however, it does actually slice correctly now. It's printing now. Estimated time for 1/2 of the sphere is 15 hours!
.
UPDATE: 08-16-2014 . The current stl WILL NOT print correctly. I'll try to fix it and get a working version uploaded sometime tomorrow. Before I uploaded this file, I ran it through Netfabb and made sure it was manifold. It checked out as manifold in Repetier V1.0.0. Then I updated to Repetier Host V1.0.1. and went to print. Now it's not manifold.

comments.author: GMBridge

comments.text: and the rim is very much 'not a solid' to sketchup & i'm too incompetent to clean it up so i can use subtract to add the countersunk holes for magnets. if anyone else is interested, these look like a good option: http://www.amazon.com/Neodymium-Magnets-inch-Disc-N48/dp/B008PT6P1Q/ (5/16 by 1/8, so slightly larger than i used, so hopefully more strength), and i'm guessing maybe 12 per rim (24 total) might be enough force to hold it together. 4.2mm radius cylinders would be enough wiggle room for the magnets to find their perfect alignment, and a height of 3.3mm might get the magnet pairs close enough for a strong attraction (or maybe 3.4 or 3.5, etc).
comments.author: GMBridge

comments.text: That's a great idea, hiding the magnets on the inside of the rim! Re: the file modifications, I'm on it.
comments.author: GMBridge

comments.text: i can't claim credit for hiding the magnets in the rim, my local hobby shop suggested countersinking them when we were checking their stock of magnets for what would fit & how close they needed to be to actually attract. also by putting them under the rim, there is less chance of a glue failure causing a magnet to migrate out of the assembly (a concern if they were surface mounted).
comments.author: tonyyoungblood

comments.text: ok, cut the slots on the interior pieces & installed more magnets (http://www.amazon.com/Neodymium-Magnets-inch-Disc-N48/dp/B008PT6P1Q/), 12 per interior piece (24 total), sufficient strength to hold it closed & lightly toss it around (a firm shake separates the orb). since i did not want to affect the detail on the interior lip, the magnets are further apart than optimal, so if the rim pieces get those counter sunk holes, those magnets would be perfect for it.
comments.author: GMBridge

comments.text: Thanks for the R&D! What I'll probably do is (in the Sketchup files) make half of the magnet hole in the rim and half in the sphere, that way it can sink a little deeper without poking through.
comments.author: GMBridge

comments.text: you could probably put 3/4 in the rim & 1/4 in the sphere, can't separate the magnets too much or their attraction falls off very fast (splitting the void like that will help align the pieces when gluing if people use glue.)

title: Sphero Ultimate Ramp Kit for the #MAKE5000 Challenge

description.text:
This is a set of ramps designed for Sphero during the #Make5000 contest.
For the press fit parts, the first version of this set has an offset of 0.1mm radius (0.2mm diameter).
This works for some printers but you may want a different offset. Let me know how much of an offset your printer needs for round snap/press fit parts and I'll upload a new version!
Most of the ramps are designed with a gentle slope for Sphero, this means they need to be placed directly on the floor. S2,S3,S4 are designed with stacking in mind.
Enjoy!

Lets find a way to get these ramps to stick to the floor!
I'll be experimenting with double stick tape, silicone rubber (The smoother it is the more friction in will have), Micro Suction Tape.
Micro Suction Tape is very strong on smooth surfaces so each ramp may only need a little piece.
Carpet will be harder. Maybe fingers/combs that dig into the carpet could be printed and attached to the bottom of ramps. We could also try putting Velcro on the bottom of the ramps.
More instructions and building guides coming soon!
Please let me know if you have any issues printing or building with this set.

This is second bed leveling method that I've tried on my Printrbot PLUS. The first worked well down to a nozzle size of 0.35 mm but I wanted to go even smaller! So I needed a design with a little less slop.

Tools required:
1) Phillips screw driver
2) 5/32" drill bit to drill out part holes, add new holes to the plywood print bed, and open up the mounting holes in the heated print bed
3) Hand drill
4) Exacto knife to clean up the first layers and clean out the holes for the hidden nut
5) Soldering iron to press the hidden captured nuts into their nut retainers so they are flush with the surface
6) Dremmel tool or saw to modify the front y-axis rod clamps Additional parts you'll need:
1) 2 x #6-32 2" screws
2) 6 x #6-32 3/4" screws
3) 4 x #6-32 1-1/2" screws
4) 6 x #6 washers
5) 8 x #8 washers
6) 12 x #6-32 nuts
7) 4 x stiff springs (NOTE: I found that the long style springs from the "seats and springs" kits sold in the faucet repair / plumbing section of Lowe's are great!) Print 8 copies of nut-retainer.stl. That's 2 nut retainers for each corner of the heated print bed- one on top of the plywood print bed and one on the bottom. The center holes of the nut retainers are for the screws that attach to the heated print bed and line up with the existing holes in the plywood print bed. One of the holes in each of the front nut retainers lines up with the screws that attach the clamps for the y-axis rods. The front nut retainers are positioned so that the remaining hole is under the heated print bed for clearance with the y-axis bearings. The back nut retainers are mirrored across the x axis of the print bed. You'll need to modify the clamps that attach the front of the plywood print bed to the y-axis rods by cutting off the neck of the part so that only the clamping portion remains. You'll have to drill a new hole closer to the gap in the clamp because the other screw hole will be removed when you cut off the neck of the part. You'll additionally need to drill out the holes in the four corners of the heated print bed so a #6-32 screw turns freely in the hole. Finally, you'll need 6 new holes in the plywood print bed so that three screws can go through each of the top nut retainers down through the plywood print bed to the bottom nut retainers. You may need to use a soldering iron to press the hidden captured nuts into the nut retainers flush with the surface so the nut retainers sit flush on the plywood print bed. This will displace some plastic in the screw hole. Just drill out the squished plastic without damaging the nuts so that the through screws will turn freely. The back nut retainers and the inside hole of the front retainers are cinched to the print bed with the following stack up:
1) #6-32 3/4" screw
2) top nut retainer
3) plywood print bed
4) #6-32 nut The y-axis clamp is remounted through the front nut retainers with the following stack up:
1) #6-32 2" screw
2) top nut retainer
3) plywood print bed
4) #6-32 nut
5) modified y-axis clamp
6) #6 washers
7) #6-32 nut The stack up of the parts (top to bottom) at each corner that mounts the heated print bed is as follows:
1) #6-32 1-1/2" screw
2) #6 washer
3) the heated print bed
4) #8 washer
5) stiff spring
6) #8 washer
7) top nut retainer
8) #6-32 nut captured between top nut retainer (center hole) and plywood print bed
9) plywood print bed
10) #6-32 nut captured between bottom nut retainer (center hole) and plywood print bed
11) bottom nut retainer Once you tighten the screw down clamping the top and bottom nut retainers to the board you may have to adjust the screws a bit so that the center screw can turn freely as it is threaded through the assembly. The height of the print bed is adjusted by turning the screws from the top of the heated print bed. You'll need to make sure that the 1-1/2" screws that attach the heated print bed turn freely enough to be able to adjust the height of the heated print bed with a Phillips screw driver, but not so freely that they'll come loose.

But this is working and I haven't gotten around to it.

A remix of Areeve20's "Sharpie Cap Screwdriver", Bulked out a bit, and added a slot where a small magnet can be mounted.
I printed this remix with a Makerbot 2 so I redesigned some components to work more smoothly with this 3d printer in particular. (I ran it at 1.2mm resolution)

NOTE: I have just updated and re-uploaded the model as for some reason it was in meters instead of millimeters. Thanks Areeve20 for pointing that out! Please download the new files! Print the cap, buy TWO D2H1 magnets, mount magnet, use as a screw driver/ sharpie cap. ( I bought mine here: http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D2H1 ) More detailed instructions:
Stick the magnets onto the flat base of a screw driver bit, and press the whole thing down into the hex-holder on the cap, this will force the magnet down into a tapered slot. Once its inserted into the slot, drop some super glue from the other side of the cap (The side that the sharpie goes into) to glue the magnet in place. Once dry just pop in your favorite bit and drive screws... or un-drive screws. Note I have included a quick video, an .STL file, and an .IGES in case anyone wanted to make changes.

description.text:
Belt connector for RigidBot, which uses a 6mm GT2 belt.  This version twists the belt so the smooth side of the belt runs along the bearing.  The 13mm version matches the height of the original part.  You may need to mirror the part to have it oriented correctly.  
Update: added an offset version for use with a 16 tooth GT2 pulley.  The offset belt adds a little bit of torque to the extruder mount when the belt is tightened so I'm not sure it's good as a long term solution.  
Warning: This part should be printed in ABS or another high temperature plastic if it is used near the extruder or heated bed.

comments.text: No, the part of the belt that is attached to the extruder or bed plate remains flat, the other side has a half-twist. I think the idea originated from http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/06/half-belt-hack.html.

Treads to try out my own TPU filament... worked great :-) For this proof of principle design I used long M6-threaded screws (the hubs/wheels were screwed onto them) and ball bearings. The fuselage is not in any way a good design, only a fast base to test the hubs/wheels/tread... the drive-wheel was fitted directly onto the geared-motor axis.
Different flexible filament would perhaps work, make sure its not too stretchy since it might not stay on the wheels/hubs. I used my own:
http://www.creativetools.se/pi-etpu-95-250-carbon-black-1kg-se It´s 95 Shore A. It is also conductive and if you make both the hubs and thread in this material you will be able to handle the static electricity that is built up when plastic moves... Please check out my unique UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. Follow me on Instagram and twitter:

description.text: These guide rings press fit into the channels of any 20mm aluminum extrusion, and help organize your wire paths. The green looks really nice when using black PET expandable sleeving :) .

The scad file allows you to set the thickness and the ring size. I find that between 12mm and 20mm is the most useful ring size, and the thickness of between 5 and 10mm is useful depending upon what kind of wire you are routing.
The current stl file has one each of a .5"  (12.5mm) and .75" (19mm) samples at 10mm thick.
I use PLA for this, as it is stiffer than ABS, but I suspect ABS would be fine.
The "clip" part of the scad file is actually separate from the ring (and unioned to it), so you could actually replace the ring part with any useful shape, for attaching stuff to an extrusion (e.g. a split ring, so that you don't have to pre-thread all the wires). Let me know what variations you come up with.
